questions.question_text:
A multinational corporation is deploying a Microsoft Power Platform solution to manage its sales processes across the following regions: North America, Europe, and Asia.

Each region operates independently but reports to a global headquarters. The company has several business units that correspond to each region. Within each business unit are multiple teams based on countries/regions.

Company employees have the following requirements:

• Sales representatives must have access only to data relevant to their specific country/region.
• Regional managers must be able to view and manage data across all areas within their region.
• Some global analysts require read-only access to sales data across the corporation by using third-party tools.
• External contractors need limited access to the system to input their progress.

You need to design a solution for the company.

What should you do?

choices.D: Use a single default business unit and manage data access through security roles.
choices.B: Implement a DLP policy to restrict data that will be shared from Microsoft Dataverse.
choices.C: Use a global security role with organization-level access for sales representatives.

To ensure that the requirement is met, you should perform the following two actions:

A. Configure the relevant connector so that it is part of the Non-Business data group category: This will ensure that the connector is compliant with regulatory requirements for handling PII data. The Non-Business data group category includes connectors that have been reviewed and approved by Microsoft as compliant with GDPR and other data protection regulations.

D. Create a Data Loss Protection (DLP) policy: This will help to prevent the unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data, including PII, by detecting and blocking attempts to share this information on social media platforms that are not authorized by the company.

why not E?
Configuring the relevant connector so that it is part of the Blocked data group category would prevent the use of the connector altogether, which is not desirable in this scenario. This would not allow the company to use the connector for posting events on authorized social media platforms. The Blocked data group category includes connectors that are not compliant with Microsoft's security and compliance standards or that have been identified as risky or potentially harmful. Therefore, using the Blocked data group category would not be an appropriate solution for ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements for handling PII data in this scenario. Instead, using the Non-Business data group category is more appropriate, as it includes connectors that are compliant with regulatory requirements for handling PII data.
